title: fredericktaylor
author: fredericktaylor
content: 1. comments.author: SquirrelJulietGarden
comments.body: The very first step and also most important is to understand "It is your key, it is your bitcoin" so that people will see it is too vital by choosing a good place to store their bitcoin.It is in non-custodial and open-source wallets. Because with those wallets, you have keys of your bitcoin and you actually control your bitcoin.Other wallets are custodial like centralized exchanges, Bitcoin Spot ETFs are not non custodial wallets so no private keys for you. If you want to have bitcoin from those platforms, you will have to submit your withdrawal request or redeem request and get approvals from them. If they don't approve your request and refuse to give you bitcoin, you will lose your bitcoin.It is vital and definitely most important step.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: These aren't steps to understand Bitcoin. This list doesn't bring anybody from zero to expert. Neither do I agree with Saylor in calling the list 21 rules of Bitcoin. These aren't Bitcoin rules. These aren't even the most important facts, principles, truths about Bitcoin. Many of what's listed are seemingly petty, trivial. This list could have been made better. Saylor could have included legitimate rules like 'not your keys, not your coins', exchanges aren't wallets, private keys aren't meant to be shared, Bitcoin isn't a get-rich quick scheme, and so on and so forth.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: Quote from: Dunamisx on February 18, 2025, 02:34:34 PMI recommend this to be included on what is needed to learn about bitcoin and how the network operates.bitcoin historyhttps://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5438353.0Mastering Bitcoinhttps://github.com/bitcoinbook/bitcoinbookJust a short review. I can guarantee beginner who knows nothing about Bitcoin and gets to read the first three chapters of this book, that you're going to understand Bitcoin at a very over high level. It connects the different pieces of together and breaks down how transactions works, how they're serialized in broadcasts to the network which allows you to start understanding how anyone can use Bitcoin and how no one can stop the transactions, how addresses were created. Also it covers a private key to a public key to an address all using elliptic curve cryptography and different elliptic curve mathematics and different cryptographic functions and hashes  and it clarified it very simply with many really good examples. At the end of the book, it will leave you feeling more confident in your knowledge of bitcoin. I highly recommend it.
